ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to create an analysis across texts
Learned how to close read literary texts.

I read some really amazing novels and gained a lot of knowledge on American literature mostly through the lens of race and class tension which was a really engaging and relevant way to assess the literature.
I gained interesting perspectives on how Americans choose to define their culture and people. This was also a good class to learn how to write a basic college essay

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Prof. Howard is great at making sure everyone feels that their contributions are valued.

The book selection was great, and I think the topics we covered were very interesting. However, I do wish that there was a little more time of each class devoted to seminar discussion. Professor Howard also graded essays a little more difficultly than expected, but not so much that it was a stressor (good for growth!).

Strength: be introduced to various pieces of American literature, especially works by Black Americans 
Weaknesses: not getting through a lot of material each class because of instructor comments.
Strengths: Professor Howard is super smart and led thoughtful discussion.

strengths: the selection of readings were all amazing and had clear relevancy to the course topic; passage assignments were really helpful for close reading practice; lots of instruction on writing skills: how to craft thesis, write intro, close read, etc

weaknesses: the paper topics were sometimes a bit vague for a introductory course; many of the novels could have used a little more time in class to unpack and discuss; some of the assignment instructions were misleading or were released very late/changed last minute which made it hard to balance coursework

The selected books made for a really interesting and excellent semester. I feel that I learned so much from every author we covered. I received thorough feedback on every essay which improved my reading comprehension and writing. I wish at times we would've had more time for class discussions, rather than comments form the professor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I think I would recommend it to any student interested in learning more about the intricacies of American Literature, but not if they want to develop complex ideas.
I would recommend the course because I think it covers a lot of really important texts, and even if the class rushes through them a bit they are still really valuable for learning.
Yes, but think of it as more of a casual lecture than a seminar.
